Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hikurangi Ocean Bottom Investigation of Tremor and Slow Slip (HOBITSS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Deployment of a network of pressure gauges and seismometers on the Hikurangi portion of the subduction zone off North Island New Zealand is designed to record a slow-slip event (SSE) expected to occur on the plate boundary fault in the 2014-2015 timeframe. SSE occur every ~18 months in this region, so documenting the deformation associated with this type of event and comparing that couple-week activity with ongoing microseismicity should illustrate the evolution of forces and associated hazards in this region. Twenty US seafloor instruments, including 10 from OBSIP, will be combined with a similar number of Japanese instruments for ~12 months. These data will be evaluated together with data from onshore geodetic and seismic stations in this international collaboration. Results will inform planning for possible future seafloor drilling by IODP and subsequent in-situ measurements.

Due to the shallow dip of the subducting plate, the Hikurangi site offers a unique opportunity to document the small signals associated with SSE, for which motion is too minor for human perception. Insights into this newly-recognized mode of plate interaction, are expected to be applicable to other convergent margins. How far 'up-dip' the slip extends, whether all the way to the seafloor near the subduction trench or not, is a key unknown in current estimates of earthquake shaking and tsunami hazard. The extent of slow slip can indicate how much stress on the plate boundary fault is relieved versus building up toward an eventual megathrust earthquake.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We deployed ocean bottom instrumentation at the northern Hikurangi subduction zone, offshore the North Island of New Zealand, to allow observations of the seismic behavior of the megathrust. Subduction zones are the site of most of the world’s largest earthquakes, with accompanying threat to populations. A spectrum of fault slip speeds at subduction zones has been identified including fast slip that produces earthquakes, aseismic slip that occurs at the plate convergence rate, and slow slip that occurs with little to no seismic energy release but can be detected by geodetic means. Slip behavior on a fault depends on the conditions on the fault interface- likely the temperature, the types of rocks across the fault, topography on the fault interface and sediments and fluids within the fault. The fault in the region this project exhibits slow-slip behavior: an intermediate state between a locked and freely slipping fault. There are multiyear intervals when the fault is locked followed by short (one-two week) intervals when parts of the fault interface slip slowly such that much of the strain accumulated over the preceding interval is released. Because of the significant societal impacts, it is important to understand which slip mode occurs where and what controls the different faulting behaviors. The shallow earthquake-generating portion of subduction zones, called the megathrust, is difficult to characterize because it is relatively inaccessible in most locations. The slow-slip events (SSEs) in the north Hikurangi region were first detected by GPS observations on land and showed that most of the slip on the fault interface was occurring offshore, but otherwise the land observations poorly constrained the location and amount of slip. The north Hikurangi (Gisborne) offshore SSEs could be detected because the coastline lies unusually close to the trench here compared to most subduction zones. The region chosen, near Gisborne NZ produced two unusual shallow "tsunami" earthquakes in 1947. Tsunami earthquakes generate larger than expected tsunamis (for the earthquake size) and are associated with slip on shallow fault interfaces. The project combined land GPS observations and offshore seafloor pressure observations with observations of seismicity from both land and ocean bottom seismometers. Seafloor pressure gauges were used (for the first time) to detect the vertical uplift of the seafloor occurring during slow slip events. Reference pressure stations on the incoming Pacific plate were used to remove oceanographic signals from the pressure on the upper plate. Pressure decreases of 150-540 Pascals (equivalent to 1.5-5.4 cm uplift of the seafloor) were observed at all of the upper plate HOBITSS absolute pressure gauge sites during the large slow slip event (SSE). Modeling of the data revealed a patch with 10 to 20 cm of slip on the fault. These data demonstrate that large SSEs can occur on the shallowest reaches of the subduction megathrust, where very low temperatures and pressures exist.

This project involved the career development of two graduate students and two undergraduate students and strengthened international collaboration between the US, New Zealand and Japan. It also engaged the local community in Gisborne and Napier, New Zealand through lectures and ship tours. Our observations show the potential for marine observations to resolve locked and unlocked regions of subduction zones and thereby get a better understanding of which parts of subduction zones are likely to produce dangerous earthquakes and tsunamis. Patchiness of fault locking is likely important to determining how large an earthquake will become thus marine data may better inform earthquake hazard mitigation.
